events.summary: Respighi popped into the world in a musical family in Bologna. His dad, a postal worker by day and pianist by night, probably had a son who could tune a piano by ear before he could even walk.

At the tender age of 12, Respighi decided that music was cooler than just playing with his toys, enrolling at the Liceo Musicale di Bologna where he dabbled in violin and composition. After a not-so-friendly encounter with a ruler, he found more patient tutors.

Respighi joined the orchestra at the Teatro Comunale, showing off his violin skills and leaving audiences wondering if they’d ever see a violinist so talented who could also snooze through a performance.

He went to Russia and ended up rubbing shoulders with his idol, Rimsky-Korsakov, who must have thought ‘This kid has potential,’ teaching Respighi orchestration and probably sharing snacks during study sessions.
Respighi finally finished his first opera, Re Enzo. This comedy left people laughing harder than they had any right to, probably forgetting that Respighi still had a day job as a violist.
His transcription of Monteverdi’s 'Lamento d'Arianna' made waves during a performance in Berlin, and he came to the realization that history was not just dusty old books but profitable!

Respighi found his way to Rome and took up a teaching post at the Liceo Musicale di Santa Cecilia, where he became a mentor to future music legends—because what else do you do when you're a musical genius?
In a classic tale of student-teacher romance, Respighi married his pupil Elsa. Their level of harmony was so good even a choir would be jealous—if only they could sing in eleven languages!

His first orchestral tone poem, Fountains of Rome, premiered to a crowd so grumpy it made winter frozen roads look pleasant. But despite the rocky reception, Respighi got a taste of the fame that would soon flow his way.

After a rough patch following his mother’s passing, Respighi found solace writing music in the peaceful hills of Eremo di Tizzano, where he probably took more naps than usual, using a dreamy melody for inspiration.

Respighi, while knee-deep in composing his opera Lucrezia, met his match with illness. It was a sad farewell, but one can imagine him leaving behind melodies that still wander the streets of Rome, refusing to become mere notes on a page.

In a dramatic twist that could rival opera plots, Respighi reluctantly picked 'Fountains of Rome' for a series of concerts in Milan, thrusting him into the spotlight. The success of these concerts turned him into an Italian musical powerhouse, and he started a tumultuous partnership with the legendary conductor Arturo Toscanini. This was the moment he realized that picking favorites could pay off handsomely!

Respighi’s summer was quite productive as he accepted a commission from Diaghilev for the Ballets Russes. He created a revised version of an Italian opera that concluded with Russian-themed dances. The ballet premiered in Paris, proving that mixing cultures in the art world was not just a modern concept but a fabulous hit!

In a delightful duo venture for the ages, Respighi and his wife Elsa embarked on their first concert tour, marking her debut as a live performer. Their journey took them across Italy and to Prague and Vienna, showcasing that musical talent runs in the family—even if it meant a stern letter from his employers about why he was away so long!

Respighi struck a creative chord with his friend Claudio Guastalla, resulting in the completion of 'Belfagor', his first opera in ten years. The opera's premiere was welcomed, marking a joy-filled return to the operatic scene without the gloom that typically followed his compositions. A true testament to the power of friendships in the arts!

events.event: Director of Conservatorio di Santa Cecilia
events.summary: Respighi found himself in a prestigious position as the first director of the state-funded Conservatorio di Santa Cecilia. Despite the title sounding impressive, he quickly grew weary of the red tape and administrative duties, deciding by 1926 that teaching was far more pleasant than paperwork—an artist's lament for the ages!

In a celebratory return to America, Respighi premiered 'Toccata per pianoforte e orchestra' at Carnegie Hall, much to the excitement of the audience. Sharing the stage with the New York Philharmonic, he showcased that every big city loves a good musical event—even if it means a fierce battle for the best piano bench!

Respighi completed his third Roman tone poem, 'Roman Festivals', in record time—just nine days! It premiered with Arturo Toscanini at Carnegie Hall, where Respighi claimed he had squeezed every bit of orchestral brilliance imaginable, marking a proud moment for anyone who ever rushed to meet a deadline and nailed it!

events.event: Membership of the Reale Accademia d'Italia
events.summary: In a rather flattering twist, Respighi was formally honored with a prestigious membership in the Reale Accademia d'Italia. It felt a bit like receiving a lifetime achievement award at the Oscars—except without the golden statue and all the flashy speeches, just pure Italian pride!

Respighi conducted his opera 'La fiamma' at the Teatro dell'Opera di Roma, marking a significant moment in his directorial career. This event showed that theatrics and composition could wonderfully coexist, even if it was a bit stressful (imagine placing a bedazzled crown on a fantastical character while conducting simultaneously).

As Respighi tried to finish his next opera 'Lucrezia', health troubles crept in like an uninvited guest. Despite his attempts to continue composing, his body had other plans, leading to the sad but relatable reality of artists battling the inevitable—proving that creativity doesn’t always cooperate with health!
Ottorino Respighi made his grand entrance into the world, ensuring that his mother would remember that day for the rest of her life—after all, it came with quite a bit of noise!.
With 'Re Enzo' hitting the stage, Respighi decided it was time to take the opera world by storm, proving that even royal figures could become dramatic stars.
'Semirâma' was like Respighi's personal audition piece for the operatic legacy, showcasing his talent and determination to make his mark.
The 'Fountains of Rome' debuted, leaving audiences wondering if there was a second composer hiding behind Respighi, because this piece was simply on another level.
When 'Pines of Rome' premiered, listeners might have thought they heard the trees whispering Respighi’s name, as nature itself became the ultimate fan of his work.
Respighi's 'The Birds' flapped its wings into the repertoire, turning concerts into a delightful aviary, and giving every birdwatcher a reason to celebrate.
In his final year, Respighi was still composing away, proving that great artists never put down their pens, not even to take a quick coffee break!
Respighi left the stage of life, but his music ensured that the show would go on, with many still marveling at his artistic brilliance.
